Posts.Content: Originally Posted by CarlaJean His PSA jumped from 1.9 a year ago to 4.5, but because of medicine he is already on for his Prostrate the doctor said it was like a 9.0 rate. He is 63. He is having his PSA checked again next week and then we meet with the doctor August 1st. If his PSA is still high we need to decide by then if we want a biopsy to determine if it is cancer. Given his age and comorbidities, a biopsy, (even a saturation biopsy) probably wouldn't hurt him, however surgery might. I understand his concerns and sympathize, however he IS still relatively young and radiation in the form of IMRT or Brachytherapy might be an option depending on the stage and grade of his disease. Try to keep your chin up. All is NOT lost!

Posts.Title: radiation after prostate removal

Posts.Content: Hi Harding, I believe you're making this issue a lot more complex than it probably is. (That's the good news.) You have a G6 which is in your favor. G6 rarely metastasizes and is generally VERY slow growing. You also don't seem to have a history of high PSA. You indicate that your treatment choice is IMRT. Be aware that radiation keeps doing it's thing for some time after the end of your sessions. Occasionally, this can be as much as 2 or 3 YEARS. The only confusing part is that using the combination of radiation and ADT, while augmenting the effects of the radiation really doesn't give a direct answer as to how effective the radiation is. In other words, the ADT will almost always lower your PSA to zero by itself even in the presence of metastatic disease. Radiation will not. Bottom line: If disease is confined to the prostate then radiation alone should eventually drop the PSA to <0.1. With the addition of ADT during the early phase, you MAY be seeing the results of the ADT and not the radiation. You would be well advised to talk this over with your Rad. Onc. Best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: What should PSA be 5 months after castration?

Posts.Content: Putt, This information was provided to me by my own radiation oncologist regarding my own case. He wanted to be as sure as possible that the radiation was truly 'killing' the tumor cells. I is common knowledge that ADT does not kill but merely controls cell proliferation for an indefinite period of time. In my case, my PSA is consistently dropping and that can be directly attributed to the radiation. If it should rise in the future, We still have the option of ADT. I personally believe that a lot of guys begin ADT too early and therefore lose a valuable weapon when the disease becomes refractory.

Posts.Title: What should PSA be 5 months after castration?

Posts.Content: It may have had something to do with the fact that I was being treated with adjuvant radiation for positive margins rather than the whole prostate. I'm not sure. His statement was: "We're fairly sure you're PSA is due to the positive margins. If we treat with just IMRT and your PSA goes down, then we KNOW we've got it. If it doesn't, we have an issue elsewhere, i.e. microscopic spread. If we use ADT at this time, we won't know for sure if the margins were the cause or not because the ADT will bring down the PSA in any case."

Posts.Title: What should PSA be 5 months after castration?

Posts.Content: Hi newporter, You are correct! To me, it seems sort of like a medical paradox. It is well established that ADT does make cancer cells more susceptible to the effects of radiation. My doc simply said that he wanted to avoid ADT so that if the PSA went down, we would know it was due to the radiation and not at least partially due to ADT suppression. Bear in mind, I'm sharing this information as it was given to me. As a total layman it is of course possible that I misunderstood. I hope not! Cheers! --- Dave

Posts.Content: Hi jfredfc, Unfortunately, this was the most reliable information I could find on this product. https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-875-l-arginine.aspx?activeingredientid=875 What do you want to use this for? In general, there is no empirical evidence that any supplement will have a curative effect on existing PCa. This particular product also may negatively interact with a number of common drugs, sometimes with potentially serious side effects. I highly recommend that you discuss this with your doctor before experimenting with it. Best of luck!

Posts.Title: L-arginine Plus

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Robnj Hi Guys, PSA has gone from 11.42 Jan. 2017 to what it is now 132.02 June 2017. Was on Xtandi for a few years, went to Zytiga which did absolutely nothing. Have been on double Degarelix shots to get Testosterone down. Which it did get it down into 20's but seems too little too late on that. Started Xofigo in March. Have done 4 shots of that...no real problems. Anyway, my oncologist would like me to stop the Xofigo, and start Taxotere immediately. I'm inclined to do the 2 more shots of Xofigo, and see where we are at that point. I didn't expect the Xofigo to drop my PSA (of course I was hoping), but I did expect it to control it somewhat. I just don't like the idea of stopping in mid stream. I have been able to keep my prostate cancer known to only my close friends & family. My physical appearance has not changed in 5 1/2 years of some form of ADT. I never wanted to be defined by my illness. Of course, once I start Taxotere and my hair falls away.....the cat is out of the bag. I know it's in my future, but would like to stay away from it as long as possible. My Onc has no other options according to her. Any input would be welcome..... Thanks guys Hi Robnj, Are you dealing an RO or an MO? I would suggest an MO at this point for sure. Have you had a bone scan yet? I can't advise you on the meds but it sounds like you're not being offered the full range of options. Keep us posted. --- Dave

He is having his PSA checked again next week and then we meet with the doctor August 1st. If his PSA is still high we need to decide by then if we want a biopsy to determine if it is cancer. Given his age and comorbidities, a biopsy, (even a saturation biopsy) probably wouldn't hurt him, however surgery might. I understand his concerns and sympathize, however he IS still relatively young and radiation in the form of IMRT or Brachytherapy might be an option depending on the stage and grade of his disease. Try to keep your chin up. All is NOT lost!

Posts.Title: My husband does not want to be tested for Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: Hi Harding, I believe you're making this issue a lot more complex than it probably is. (That's the good news.) You have a G6 which is in your favor. G6 rarely metastasizes and is generally VERY slow growing. You also don't seem to have a history of high PSA. You indicate that your treatment choice is IMRT. Be aware that radiation keeps doing it's thing for some time after the end of your sessions. Occasionally, this can be as much as 2 or 3 YEARS. The only confusing part is that using the combination of radiation and ADT, while augmenting the effects of the radiation really doesn't give a direct answer as to how effective the radiation is. In other words, the ADT will almost always lower your PSA to zero by itself even in the presence of metastatic disease. Radiation will not. Bottom line: If disease is confined to the prostate then radiation alone should eventually drop the PSA to <0.1. With the addition of ADT during the early phase, you MAY be seeing the results of the ADT and not the radiation. You would be well advised to talk this over with your Rad. Onc. Best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Content: It may have had something to do with the fact that I was being treated with adjuvant radiation for positive margins rather than the whole prostate. I'm not sure. His statement was: "We're fairly sure you're PSA is due to the positive margins. If we treat with just IMRT and your PSA goes down, then we KNOW we've got it. If it doesn't, we have an issue elsewhere, i.e. microscopic spread. If we use ADT at this time, we won't know for sure if the margins were the cause or not because the ADT will bring down the PSA in any case."

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Robnj Hi Guys, PSA has gone from 11.42 Jan. 2017 to what it is now 132.02 June 2017. Was on Xtandi for a few years, went to Zytiga which did absolutely nothing. Have been on double Degarelix shots to get Testosterone down. Which it did get it down into 20's but seems too little too late on that. Started Xofigo in March. Have done 4 shots of that...no real problems. Anyway, my oncologist would like me to stop the Xofigo, and start Taxotere immediately. I'm inclined to do the 2 more shots of Xofigo, and see where we are at that point. I didn't expect the Xofigo to drop my PSA (of course I was hoping), but I did expect it to control it somewhat. I just don't like the idea of stopping in mid stream. I have been able to keep my prostate cancer known to only my close friends & family. My physical appearance has not changed in 5 1/2 years of some form of ADT. I never wanted to be defined by my illness. Of course, once I start Taxotere and my hair falls away.....the cat is out of the bag. I know it's in my future, but would like to stay away from it as long as possible. My Onc has no other options according to her. Any input would be welcome..... Thanks guys Hi Robnj, Are you dealing an RO or an MO? I would suggest an MO at this point for sure. Have you had a bone scan yet? I can't advise you on the meds but it sounds like you're not being offered the full range of options. Keep us posted. --- Dave

Posts.Title: Xofigo/Taxotere

Posts.Content: Hi jfredfc, Unfortunately, this was the most reliable information I could find on this product. https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-875-l-arginine.aspx?activeingredientid=875 What do you want to use this for? In general, there is no empirical evidence that any supplement will have a curative effect on existing PCa. This particular product also may negatively interact with a number of common drugs, sometimes with potentially serious side effects. I highly recommend that you discuss this with your doctor before experimenting with it. Best of luck!

Posts.Title: L-arginine Plus

Posts.Content: Putt, This information was provided to me by my own radiation oncologist regarding my own case. He wanted to be as sure as possible that the radiation was truly 'killing' the tumor cells. I is common knowledge that ADT does not kill but merely controls cell proliferation for an indefinite period of time. In my case, my PSA is consistently dropping and that can be directly attributed to the radiation. If it should rise in the future, We still have the option of ADT. I personally believe that a lot of guys begin ADT too early and therefore lose a valuable weapon when the disease becomes refractory.

Posts.Content: Hi newporter, You are correct! To me, it seems sort of like a medical paradox. It is well established that ADT does make cancer cells more susceptible to the effects of radiation. My doc simply said that he wanted to avoid ADT so that if the PSA went down, we would know it was due to the radiation and not at least partially due to ADT suppression. Bear in mind, I'm sharing this information as it was given to me. As a total layman it is of course possible that I misunderstood. I hope not! Cheers! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Where is ForumBrother FeatherBoy?

Posts.Content: Hi DanaATX If I understand your question correctly, It seems to be the issue of picking a good RO. I got very lucky with mine and I stand by that. Choose one who your providers think highly of and would go to if necessary. Whatever mode of radiation you choose, follow their instruction EXACTLY TO THE LETTER! If they tell you to have a full bladder before treatment, be damn sure you do it, even if it is uncomfortable. If they tell you to lie perfectly still during active treatment, don't even move a muscle until they ok it. Failure in following simple instructions can result in disastrous consequences later in life I know, been there, done it, bought the tee shirt. Radiation in the proper hands can potentially cure cancer if you are careful. I wasn't and am paying for it for the rest of my life! I hope I haven't scared you off radiation, that was not my intent! Just do your homework and talk to as many ROs as possible. Cheers and Keep the faith! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Pelvic MRI today

Posts.Content: Hello Tiger, So sorry you need to be here. We all understand your concerns. Could you provide us with his post-op PSA? A G 3+4= 7 is mildly aggressive as as opposed to an 8,9 or 10. The fact that your doctor is comfortable waiting 4 months before radiation suggests that he is still shooting for a cure. This is a case where you really need to ask direct questions of him. Keep in mind that, although metastatic/systemic disease is generally thought to be incurable, this is not always the case. If the only spread is ACTUALLY contained in the pelvic area, it is possible that whole pelvic radiation will result in a cure. Also, keep in mind that there is a difference between the terms "chronic" and "terminal". They are not the same. If he does need ADT, the disease will become chronic, with the real possibility of one or more remissions. Your husband is VERY young but with careful management, he could have MANY good years ahead These are all points that you need to cover with your doctor. I wish you the best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LL Fauntleroy Just back from the consult with the urology oncologist. This facility offers RRP and EBRT & seeds. He basically said surgery is my best option, however, I had 8 cores positive both sides, plus the largest involvement in the apex and base, not good for being completely contained, T1C staging(for now) which is why I am told by others, that radiation would be the best approach...So, the RO and the surgeon are completely at both ends of the spectrum.. Is there an unbiased physician or service that one can go to for help in deciding which treatment is best, based on personal stats? The detail about the surgery was sobering, especially with the apex involvement, urinary sphincter, cutting the urethra, possible nerve and lymph node removal.... Fauntleroy I don't understand how you can be staged as T1c with positive cores on BOTH sides. That would be a T2c or greater. (See link: http://prostatecancer101.org/staging.html) The main issue here is that every case is different. The outcome is based more on (1) how advanced the disease is at diagnoses and (2) the experience and skill of the treatment provider. These facts are well established in the medical community. Unfortunately, doctors cannot make the decision for you, mainly due to liability issues. All things being equal, recent studies clearly show there is little difference between the top three standard treatments (Surgery, Brachytherapy & Ext.Radiation) in the same situation. I'm sure the others will have more input on this. Best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate I would suggest that you request a PHI blood test. It includes psa, free psa, a marker for prostate cancer activity, and a formula to provide a score of the liklihood of a biopsy finding prostate cancer. It is less sensitive to benign prostatitis spikes than just psa. There are some infection risks with biopsies, and a PHI test can help determine if one is really necessary. The blood must be drawn before any rectal exam, and the urologist should know that. Hi dth32, The advice ASA just gave you was excellent! Before his post, I had not heard of the PHI test. Posts.Title: worried

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Big_Bob Gentleman: I'm new here and was diagnosed in April 2017. After considering my options, I've elected to go with the DaVinci Surgery next month. I had laproscopic hernia surgery 8 years ago which was more pain than I expected but I recovered quickly (running again after 2 weeks). My only concern is the catheter part which gives me willies.....Wish me luck next month and thanks for sharing your experiences. Bob Hi Bob and welcome to the forum, This is a common concern for many men. Please rest assured it is more of a nuisance than anything else. You will not be awake when they place the catheter and you may not even be aware of its presence until you start moving around. After that, it is simply more of an inconvenience than anything else. When it is time to remove it, the removal may be done either by your provider or yourself. The little water balloon in your bladder is deflated and the catheter will slide right out. No pain. The most important thing to remember to keep the genital area and especially the area where the tubing enters the penis extremely clean. You will be instructed on proper catheter care before you are discharged. I hope this helps to allay some of your fears. Cheers! --- Dave

Posts.Content: Hi Chief, Your situation sounds very similar to mine. The damn bladder/urethral spasms kept on for the duration of the time on the catheter! Royal pain but nothing to worry about. Definitely try to avoid things that irritate the urinary tract such as coffee, tea , alcohol etc. As to the drain, I assume you have a Jackson-Pratt as I did. They are necessary to prevent fluid buildup such as blood, pus or other fluids. They are very commonly used and need only to be kept clean. I was in the hospital for 3 days and the drain was removed before I was discharged. The little puncture where the drain is will heal rapidly after removal. And yes, a good wife IS a Godsend. I know mine is. Keep her as they are few and far between nowadays! Best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Content: Hi Warren, Truth be told, it is likely that we will have to approve your membership. The rapid rise in PSA plus the low free PSA coupled with your age and the rapid increase in size of your prostate unfortunately smacks pf early PCa. Now the good news: If you have to have cancer, PCa is the one to have. You have acted early and, assuming you are in reasonably decent health otherwise, you can probably expect to see at least 80 years, possibly more with the current treatments. There is also the possibility of a full cure and your biopsy results will help us make more informed comments. Keep us in the loop regarding your treatment choices (assuming you DO become a member). Best of luck and don't panic! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Surprising but hopefully good news

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walt_Green not to pic nits here, but the OP did Watchful Wait, not Active Surveillance. there is a very big difference! Unless I read it incorrectly, he went 2 years (perhaps 3?) in between biopsies, and only had PSA's every 6 months. IIRC, AS requires yearly biopsies as well as PSA tests every three months. As for the OP, I would recommend a he get second opinion on the G8 scoring. His PSA is *extremely* low for his age. Even if scaled back to a G7a or 7b, he should still treat, of course. But, there's a world of difference between G7a/b or G8. For those quick to criticize WW/AS, the OP has had three years of normal life. His scans are negative. Even if he has to treat now, he's LOST NOTHING. on the other hand, he has gained THREE YEARS OF NORMAL LIFE. Given his age, his WW was a smart play. He's lost nothing, only gained. Walt, As you can see here, there is currently no clear definition of either one. It just depends on what the physician chooses to call it. Either way, they both carry inherent risks. http://www.cancer.org/cancer/prostat...tchful-waiting

Posts.Title: Men with recurring prostate cancer not dying from prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by akai Hi Jim 215, thanks for the suggestion. Johns Hopkins confirmed the results and also upgraded one of the 3+4 to 3+5, then added another 3+3 of less than 5%. I was diagnosed with 3+3 in August 2012, tracking PSA religiously, every three to four months at two different places to avoid false readings. One Prolaris Test, low risk of 2%. Two Oncotype DX tests, low risk. Two subsequent biopsied from first Bx showed G6s. PSA gradually rose from 3.2 to 5.3, brought that up with my uro but my uro just said PSA was not the best indication. Last Bx on 05/05/2017, one G9, one G8, one G7, two G6s. I think the first three biopsied missed the G9, genomic tests gave me false sense of security, they are only as good as the samples tested. All biopsies were T3MRI fused, two at USC and two at UCLA. MRI never picked up this G9 or G8 spots. I thought that the 3TMRI would pick up aggressive type of PCa but apparently not. The G9 spot was from the systematic 12 samples not from the targeted spots pointed by the MRI. It is not a good idea to be PSA tested at different labs because the assays they use are often different. You need to be sure the assays are exactly the same.

Posts.Title: active watch for 2 years and now gleason 8...what now

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gurley43 I started my prostate cancer awareness completely by chance with a urinary track exam in 2010 and decided to have biopsies. Can't remember any thoughts or concerns about cancer at that time and the biopsy was recommended as precautionary due to my age. Had the 12 part test and 2 cells of the 12 came back with slow growth non aggressive results. First urologist said remove the prostate now. 2nd said with my results and low PSA recommended the watchful wait. In the 2010 time frame my pas was 1.6. PSA test have been conducted every 6 months. All around 2 with little change. 2 months ago I had the second biopsy and 2 cells came back active one with a gleason score of 8 and my PSA rose to 2.6, still fairly low. But with the gleason score I know something should be done. I just cant seem to come to a conclusion on what would be best. I will be 70 in Oct and am healthy and enjoy a good life with my children who live close by and my wife of 33 years. Of course, I want to live as long as possible but I worry about the side effects of the various treatments. Any thoughts on my situation would be appreciated. I wanted to mention too that I had a bone scan and complete MRI and both came back favorable with no cancer detection beyond the prostrate. Hi gurley 43, So sorry you need to be here! This is a classic example of the drawbacks of AS. Sometimes you can get away with it and sometimes you can't. In any case, waiting for a prolonged period of time with ANY active cancer is playing 'Russian Roulette' with your future. With G8 disease, I suggest that you consider either surgery or radiation with curative intent if your medical team feels that the disease is still confined. G8 can be quite aggressive so this is not the time to wait around pondering options. You already did that. Assuming the disease really is totally confined to the gland, you may still have a good chance of a cure. You are young enough to make this course of action reasonable. You need to meet with your medical team and treat this aggressively. Best of luck!

Posts.Title: active watch for 2 years and now gleason 8...what now

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gurley43 I started my prostate cancer awareness completely by chance with a urinary track exam in 2010 and decided to have biopsies. Can't remember any thoughts or concerns about cancer at that time and the biopsy was recommended as precautionary due to my age. Had the 12 part test and 2 cells of the 12 came back with slow growth non aggressive results. First urologist said remove the prostate now. 2nd said with my results and low PSA recommended the watchful wait. In the 2010 time frame my pas was 1.6. PSA test have been conducted every 6 months. All around 2 with little change. 2 months ago I had the second biopsy and 2 cells came back active one with a gleason score of 8 and my PSA rose to 2.6, still fairly low. But with the gleason score I know something should be done. I just cant seem to come to a conclusion on what would be best. I will be 70 in Oct and am healthy and enjoy a good life with my children who live close by and my wife of 33 years. Of course, I want to live as long as possible but I worry about the side effects of the various treatments. Any thoughts on my situation would be appreciated. I wanted to mention too that I had a bone scan and complete MRI and both came back favorable with no cancer detection beyond the prostrate. Hi gurley 43, So sorry you need to be here! This is a classic example of the drawbacks of AS. Sometimes you can get away with it and sometimes you can't. In any case, waiting for a prolonged period of time with ANY active cancer is playing 'Russian Roulette' with your future. With G8 disease, I suggest that you consider either surgery or radiation with curative intent if your medical team feels that the disease is still confined. G8 can be quite aggressive so this is not the time to wait around pondering options. You already did that. Assuming the disease really is totally confined to the gland, you may still have a good chance of a cure. You are young enough to make this course of action reasonable. You need to meet with your medical team and treat this aggressively. Best of luck!

Posts.Title: Men with recurring prostate cancer not dying from prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Rich S So was having a bit of a problem with urination, burning, weak flow, up every hour or so at night. At 56 I figured it was just part of getting older and was looking at a swollen prostate and perhaps a urinary tract infection. Doc says no problem, you have kidney stones. drink lots of water and things will be cool. Two weeks later and no improvement so back to the same practice, different doctor who rushes me off for lab work..... PSA = 180.8 The dreaded finger showed a hard lumpy prostate that really had no feeling when poked and prodded which seemed to really concern the urologist so it was immediately off for a needle biopsy. Not a pleasant process to have 16 holes punched in that part of the world but much to my surprise I did make it through. The Doc was somewhat vague in his answers (or more likely I was too rattled to listen) so I bring these questions to this forum for a answer from those that know firsthand. (1) My biopsy was yesterday morning, how long should I expect the blood in the urine to continue? It is not a huge amount but it is quite disturbing to see.... (2)I am somewhat concerned about "doing # 2" in light of all the punctures that were made during the biopsy, do I need to be? Thanks in advance... Oh and real irony...... I retire in four weeks, sometimes life really sucks Hi Rich! Welcome to the board and so sorry you may join us. Based on my own experience, you MAY have a little pinkish tinge now and then even after two or three weeks. Everyone is different. My own urologist/surgeon warner me about that. Try not to let that add to your existing worries. As to the #2, I am making the assumption that you either are or were on a short course of antibiotics. This is standard procedure. If you took the meds as instructed, there is little or no risk in having regular bowel movements. Thousands upon thousands of prostatic biopsies are done every year and morbidity is EXTREMELY low! Here's hoping you don't need to join us! Best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Wow...

Posts.Content: Prato, You are beginning to let this dominate your life. Once you do that, it becomes a rut that's very difficult to get out of. Try to accept the fact that your condition is what it is. We are all the same here in that regard. You are probably never going to die from prostate cancer but you may very well kill yourself due to stress alone! I know what it's like to obsess. I am a lifelong OCD sufferer. Give yourself a break. Try to forget the cancer until they tell you to worry, which may never happen. All the best! --- Dave

Thinking of you! --- Dave

Not a pleasant process to have 16 holes punched in that part of the world but much to my surprise I did make it through. The Doc was somewhat vague in his answers (or more likely I was too rattled to listen) so I bring these questions to this forum for a answer from those that know firsthand. (1) My biopsy was yesterday morning, how long should I expect the blood in the urine to continue? It is not a huge amount but it is quite disturbing to see.... (2)I am somewhat concerned about "doing # 2" in light of all the punctures that were made during the biopsy, do I need to be? Thanks in advance... Oh and real irony...... I retire in four weeks, sometimes life really sucks Hi Rich! Welcome to the board and so sorry you may join us. Based on my own experience, you MAY have a little pinkish tinge now and then even after two or three weeks. Everyone is different. My own urologist/surgeon warner me about that. Try not to let that add to your existing worries. As to the #2, I am making the assumption that you either are or were on a short course of antibiotics. This is standard procedure. If you took the meds as instructed, there is little or no risk in having regular bowel movements. Thousands upon thousands of prostatic biopsies are done every year and morbidity is EXTREMELY low! Here's hoping you don't need to join us! Best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Content: mtnbikerth, The combination of a palpable nodule plus a 6 month doubling time is cause for concern. Even though your PSA is currently very low, it is important to rule out a non-typical variant. Certain tumors produce very little PSA and are therefore harder to detect and confirm. Only your doctor can correctly advise you but if he/she recommends a biopsy, I strongly recommend you have it done. Others here may have different opinions. Best of luck to you. --- Dave

Posts.Title: Good News For All You CRPC guys....

Posts.Content: Hi fatherbuild, Could you please post your father's post-surgical stats in as much detail as possible? This will help others to give you more accurate information. You're father's symptoms are quite common at this stage of the game. Post surgical issues are different for everyone and nearly impossible to predict with any accuracy. It sounds like they removed more lymph nodes than is commonly done. If that is the case, it would at least partially account for the peripheral edema. This would be a good question for his surgeon. The most important thing right now is to maintain close communication with his medical team, especially his surgeon. All the best of luck!

Posts.Content: Well Guys, Looks like I will be leaving the '<0.1 Club'. As you see from the signature, I missed the boat this time. Doubling time around three months. I will not see my granddaughter grow up. Gleason 7 IS NOT an indolent disease. I caught it as early as it could have been caught, still, I'm not gonna win. Don't believe all the hype regarding AS. It's unproven crap. ALL cancers have the potential to spread. Understand that. Cheers!

Posts.Title: Post Pathology Report

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Derkie54 As you can see from my stats Gleason 4+3=7 & high PSA's. Next week having MRI and bone scans so I have not got any treatment plan yet. Reading the posts some of you have treatment over long periods such as " external beam radiation, 5 weeks, 15 minutes a day, five days a week " Is it normal to try and carry on working through all this or is it too much. What can I expect ? Hi Derkie, All cases are different however I can give you my own experience, so far. I am being treated for post-surgical positive margins. The technology is IMRT and the dose is 80gy over 7 weeks delivered to the prostatic fossa. I am on session #26 (I think) out of 35. So far, I am experiencing both urinary AND bowel urgency and frequency however both are fairly mild and more of an annoyance than a real problem. My best advise to you if you go this route is to take off work if possible. You may find yourself needing to be close to a restroom most of the time for a while so whether that is a practical option would depend on the kind of work that you do. Hope this was helpful. --- Dave

Posts.Content: Just got back from my first official 3 month check up since surgery. DRE was fine. Got blood drawn for first PSA. Should hear about that in three or four days. (Here goes the anxiety again!) If PSA is <0.1 We can wait another three months. If not, he DEFINITELY wants me to do radiotherapy. It seems I need to make a choice here. Adjuvant or salvage. With adjuvant, I start radiation now even with a zero PSA based on the positive margins. With salvage, We wait and see what happens down the line. My MAIN concern is if I opt for salvage, if and when it becomes necessary, am I increasing my risk for distant mets? I'm not as concerned about treatment side effects as I am in eradicating the cancer! I'm sort of asking, what would you guys choose if this was your case? Thanks for any input!

Posts.Content: Hi all! My name is Dave. I'm a 59 year old, semi-retired maintenance mechanic and professional grandpa. I'm also a brand new prostate cancer patient. I was diagnosed with stage pT2c carcinoma on my Mother's birthday, June 19th, 2012, two days after Father's Day. (Nice Father's Day present!) Lol! I have a wonderful wife of 22 years and a 30 year old son from a previous marriage. He is a staff sergeant and an F-16 mechanic in the USAF. He and his wife recently brought my brand new granddaughter into the world. It's been nearly 3 months and reality of the diagnosis is still sinking in. I'm still sort of numb! Am I going to live to see my granddaughter grow up? Will I see her get married. Am I asking too much? I still have a constant tension in my stomach. I tend to obsess over things that may or may not ever happen. I'm sure you guys have NEVER heard THAT before. Oddly, the diagnoses didn't come as a surprise as the disease killed my father at 63 and his brother in his early 70s. I was just hoping to get lucky and somehow avoid it. No luck! I underwent surgery (Open RRP) on July 16th and things seem to be going well so far. I get my first post-op DRE and PSA in about two weeks. Posts.Content: Just got back from my first official 3 month check up since surgery. DRE was fine. Got blood drawn for first PSA. Should hear about that in three or four days. (Here goes the anxiety again!) If PSA is <0.1 We can wait another three months. If not, he DEFINITELY wants me to do radiotherapy. It seems I need to make a choice here. Adjuvant or salvage. With adjuvant, I start radiation now even with a zero PSA based on the positive margins. With salvage, We wait and see what happens down the line. My MAIN concern is if I opt for salvage, if and when it becomes necessary, am I increasing my risk for distant mets? I'm not as concerned about treatment side effects as I am in eradicating the cancer! I'm sort of asking, what would you guys choose if this was your case? Thanks for any input!

Posts.Content: Hi all! My name is Dave. I'm a 59 year old, semi-retired maintenance mechanic and professional grandpa. I'm also a brand new prostate cancer patient. I was diagnosed with stage pT2c carcinoma on my Mother's birthday, June 19th, 2012, two days after Father's Day. (Nice Father's Day present!) Lol! I have a wonderful wife of 22 years and a 30 year old son from a previous marriage. He is a staff sergeant and an F-16 mechanic in the USAF. He and his wife recently brought my brand new granddaughter into the world. It's been nearly 3 months and reality of the diagnosis is still sinking in. I'm still sort of numb! Am I going to live to see my granddaughter grow up? Will I see her get married. Am I asking too much? I still have a constant tension in my stomach. I tend to obsess over things that may or may not ever happen. I'm sure you guys have NEVER heard THAT before. Oddly, the diagnoses didn't come as a surprise as the disease killed my father at 63 and his brother in his early 70s. I was just hoping to get lucky and somehow avoid it. No luck! I underwent surgery (Open RRP) on July 16th and things seem to be going well so far. I get my first post-op DRE and PSA in about two weeks. My urologist says the only thing that worries him is the positive margins. I worry that it just couldn't be that easy. These forums seem to be very well run and informative. Sorry about the rambling intro! I am not normally the type to make a nuisance of myself and I would be very pleased to be accepted into "The Club".

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon One of my best friends from Germany has his PHD in mechanical engineering and at one time was a prof at the university in Berlin before going to the private sector. He too requires every minute detail in his health care. He had a serious back operation a while back and actually told the surgeon he wanted to inspect the screws that would be used . The surgeon was not a happy camper but knew my friend and so he did. My friend said they would not work and insisted on heavier screws. He got the heavier screws. Not sure it made the difference but he has been in constant pain with his back ever since. I told him he is the smartest person I know of about motors but he doesn't know crap about fixing the body. In the same situation I would have told the surgeon that the screws was going to use looked just great. In fact I would never have asked to see them. B I can't BELIEVE the surgeon actually deffered to the patient!

Posts.Content: Hi Bad68RS! Sorry you have to join the club but I don't see any reason for you to be losing optimism at this point. First of all, your prostate weight of 20 grams is perfectly normal. Second, at least according to your biopsy report, you likely have a g6 which is a minimal threat to your life despite the 5 out of 6 positive cores on the right. Even with extracapsular extension, g6 has a well-documented reputation for NOT metastasizing. Actually, I would trade my stats for yours any day! My personal advice would be to sit back, take a deep breath, have a nice drink, follow your provider's advice and stop relying on Dr. Google. Best of luck!

Posts.Title: Second PSA

Posts.Content: Hi Ron, I have absolutely NO business giving out advice as I am not only a newbie to this forum but also a newbie to PCa, as well! That being said, I defer to the guys here with FAR more experience than I. I am responding to your post because your case seems extremely similar to mine. I also lost my father to PCa at age 63 and I fully understand what you are going through right now. I also had "a firmness" on the right side that even my PCP couldn't feel. I was TOTALLY asymptomatic at biopsy. If your urologist has recommended biopsy, please DO IT! It is sometimes uncomfortable but not painful. (If I can get through it, ANYBODY can!) You will here scare stories on Dr. Google. Most are GREATLY exaggerated! More like a "minor pain in the ass". Your doubling time of 15 months is favorable, as opposed to 3-6-9 months. The longer, the better according to my research. As far as the DRE raising your PSA, yes, it is possible, but here I defer to those with more experience. Above all, DO NOT PANIC! I realize that statement alone will do nothing to allay your immediate fears but understand that, based on the information you currently have, if you DO have PCa, you are most likely getting it at an early stage with an excellent chance of cure. Please keep in touch! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Just want to get some advice.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter Kazzie61, In addition to what HighlandCFH said, another important point is to ask him about going forward plans. With aggressive cases, one should prepare for the worst but hope for the best. Hopefully everything will work out for him but ask his urologist about his views on adjuvant vs salvage radiation and if he recommend going ahead with adjuvant, would he also recommend adding hormone therapy prior/during/after adjuvant radiation. There were studies that indicated for very high risk cases, adjuvant radiation plus hormone offers better odds of getting rid of the cancer. Also ask him for a referral to a radiation oncologist and/or an oncologist for a second opinion consult. Best of luck to you and your husband. They may want to be proactive with the Rad Onc. as to the the availability/wait time for a LINAC if he DOES need radiation. They seem to be in short supply in the UK and he will want to act quickly.

Posts.Content: jfd, Those Sloan-Kettering nomograms have been around a long tome and are a bit outdated, by SKs own admission. Updates based on recent data are probably in the works. That being said, any results gleaned from a nomogram are only as good as the data submitted. I would strongly advise you to use these tools carefully and share the results with your doctor as he/she is most qualified to interpret them. Best of luck!

Posts.Title: Just want to get some advice.....

Posts.Content: Hi Ron, I have absolutely NO business giving out advice as I am not only a newbie to this forum but also a newbie to PCa, as well! That being said, I defer to the guys here with FAR more experience than I. I am responding to your post because your case seems extremely similar to mine. I also lost my father to PCa at age 63 and I fully understand what you are going through right now. I also had "a firmness" on the right side that even my PCP couldn't feel. I was TOTALLY asymptomatic at biopsy. If your urologist has recommended biopsy, please DO IT! It is sometimes uncomfortable but not painful. (If I can get through it, ANYBODY can!) You will here scare stories on Dr. Google. Most are GREATLY exaggerated! More like a "minor pain in the ass". Your doubling time of 15 months is favorable, as opposed to 3-6-9 months. The longer, the better according to my research. As far as the DRE raising your PSA, yes, it is possible, but here I defer to those with more experience. Above all, DO NOT PANIC! I realize that statement alone will do nothing to allay your immediate fears but understand that, based on the information you currently have, if you DO have PCa, you are most likely getting it at an early stage with an excellent chance of cure. Please keep in touch! --- Dave

Posts.Title: where i am

Posts.Content: Hi!, I can certainly understand your situation! I'm basically in the same boat, but probably quite a bit worse. In 2012, I had a radical prostatectomy followed by radiation for positive margins. 3 years later, I find myself with radiation induced cystitis and uncontrollable incontinence. Because of this, I'm seriously considering looking into the same thing you are. I wish I could offer you some sound, concrete advice both on the procedure in the device itself but because I'm looking into it for the first time myself, that will be difficult. I'm planning on following this thread and will post when I get any kind of new information. You indicate that you have mild incontinence which is gradually getting worse. In my situation, I am literally confined to diapers and if I walk around the urine just comes out as it's produced, I have no sphincter control. Do keep in mind that this is open, abdominal surgery although it's considered quite safe. However, from what I read, it is generally considered as a last resort. My advice is to do your homework as best you can, discuss this with your medical team and go with what you feel is going to fit your lifestyle in the long run. I have been away from this board for quite a long time and I'm just getting back on board. I wish you the very best of luck with this and I'm looking forward to see progress updates. Cheers!

Posts.Title: Post Surgery; blood in urine.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Janei1 I haven't posted much but did learn a lot when my husband was diagnosed. He had Davinci last Feb and recoverd very well with no after effects. My question is he has developed what we believe to be a Hernia where the laparoscopic hole is where the take out the prostate. We see our surgeon in two we but have been told to see a general surgeon. Can these hernias be repaired laparoscopically or do they do an open surgery. Does anyone know the medical term for this particular hernia. Thank. If it IS a hernia, it's an incisional hernia. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incisional_hernia

Posts.Title: Surgery Is Over

Posts.Content: Hi Guarnera, This is precisely what makes this disease so frustrating. The fact is, at the end of the day, how long you live, with or without active disease is directly proportional to how well and for how long you respond favorably to various treatment options. This is why your oncologist was "kind of slippery" in her response. Stats are confusing, even to them! There are also lots of unanswered questions such as how can a G6 succumb in a year or two when a G10 might live 20+ years! These are extreme cases, of course but they can still happen. The end result of all this is worry and frustration on the part of the patient who has little or no control over the situation. All this being said, the good news, (and there is some) is that if you MUST have cancer, PCa is the one to have and now is the time to have it. --- Dave

Posts.Content: Hi, Please give us as many post-op stats as you can. Otherwise, opinions here are pure speculation. That being said, you almost definitely have a bio-chemical recurrence. You will probably be told that an upward trend over at least 2 tests needs to be established. If there IS an upward trend then you will probably need hormone therapy to control it. Best of luck and keep us posted!

Posts.Title: Totally Shocked, and not in a good way

Posts.Content: Hi Tom, Getting right to he point, the supplements may very well be masking your true PSA. You don't say what you've been taking but there are a number out there that are well known to do that. The most common one is probably saw palmetto which is commonly used to reduce the symptoms pf BPH. Based on the time frame and your G scores, I highly doubt that you've waited too long however, bear in mind your cancer IS NOT being cured by a holistic approach. I think you've made a wise choice as far as treatment. Just stay healthy with a balanced diet and plenty of exercise and I'm sure you'll be around a LONG time. Best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Surgery on Wednesday

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate I will echo Pratoman's opinions. I have been on medicare for eight years, and, between that and my supplemental insurance, have not paid a dime of my own pocket. Medicare is a great example of a single-payer system. Canada also passed a Medicare law in 1965, except theirs is for all ages, not just those over 65. I am now in Canada, where I spend much of my time, and I can tell you that Canadians are very pleased with their system. The oft-told myths about coming to the States for treatment and long wait times are mostly false. I have yet to meet a single Canadian who had to go to the States for treatment. On a global scale, EVERY other nation, rich and poor, that you can name, has "socialized medicine". And, the USA is about number 53 in life expectancy. So much for us having a superior medical system. Sad, isn't it?

Posts.Title: Scared after prostate surgery and radiation failure, please adivise

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Surgery was Monday. It was a terrible day. We arrived at 10AM for a procedure that was supposed to take less than an hour. Around noon we were told the surgeon would be delayed about an hour, so I sent my wife home. I remember they finally wheeled me into the OR at 2PM. Next thing I remember was being wheeled into a room where my wife was waiting at 6PM. The day finally ended after 8PM with the Dr inserting a Foley cath. What happened in the meantime? I suspect that I was "out" much longer than expected. I do remember someone telling me "you don't remember because of the drugs we gave you". Well if such drugs exist then I want some NOW because my head keeps going back to that day. Today I had my first followup. The Foley was out briefly, then went back in for another week. I'm still pretty beat up but am gradually returning to normal. I have to keep reminding myself that I am doing this not to be pad free but so I can start radiation before the cancer spreads any further. Looking forward to rejoining the group here... Hi Rob! Sorry to hear about the experience with Mr. Foley! Mine was installed while I was still out...fortunately! Was this done here or in the UK? Hang in there, you should be fine though it may take a while. Cheers! ---Dave

Posts.Title: AUS is in

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Surgery was Monday. It was a terrible day. We arrived at 10AM for a procedure that was supposed to take less than an hour. Around noon we were told the surgeon would be delayed about an hour, so I sent my wife home. I remember they finally wheeled me into the OR at 2PM. Next thing I remember was being wheeled into a room where my wife was waiting at 6PM. The day finally ended after 8PM with the Dr inserting a Foley cath. What happened in the meantime? I suspect that I was "out" much longer than expected. I do remember someone telling me "you don't remember because of the drugs we gave you". Well if such drugs exist then I want some NOW because my head keeps going back to that day. Today I had my first followup. The Foley was out briefly, then went back in for another week. I'm still pretty beat up but am gradually returning to normal. I have to keep reminding myself that I am doing this not to be pad free but so I can start radiation before the cancer spreads any further. Looking forward to rejoining the group here... Hi Rob! Sorry to hear about the experience with Mr. Foley! Mine was installed while I was still out...fortunately! Was this done here or in the UK? Hang in there, you should be fine though it may take a while. Cheers! ---Dave

Posts.Title: It's That Time Again!

Posts.Content: Hi Gary, Yeah, I realize that and stated so in the message. The primary info on the radiation/bleeding thing was from my own RO during my initial consultation with him. According to him, radiation damage is not tissue specific. It can and does damage all healthy tissue as well as malignant tissue. It just does more damage to cancer cells because of their increased rate of mitosis. Normal tissue can usually repair itself. In the course of the healing process, both normal and abnormal tissues sometimes become more fragile and subject to things like spontaneous bleeding, etc. In this case, he was referring to the bladder and urethra and especially the suture line between the two which might not be fully healed at the time of irradiation. As I previously mentioned, my brother in law STILL has occasional light bleeding during urination nearly 10 years out! In any case, if properly treated, I have no doubt that you'll do fine! Cheers! --- Dave

I'm thinking of trying that for myself. --- Dave

Posts.Title: Incontinence suggestions for returning to work after Prostate Surgery

Posts.Content: Hi gfr1n51, If your current PSA is <0.1 it is unlikely that you have any prostate tissue or tumor recurrence. Regarding the bleeding, sometimes a little blood can seem like a great deal, depending on the situation. Bleeding after radiation therapy is quite common and can occur MANY years after the fact. 49 treatments is tough on delicate tissues. If you haven't already done so, you may want to run this issue by your radiation oncologist for his or her input. Good luck & good health! --- Dave

Posts.Title: New to prostate cancer here's my story

Posts.Content: Cleech, Excellent information...however... Cancer is STILL cancer and the earlier it is treated, the better. If you Know you have cancer, it would be a HUGE mistake to wait, even with a low PSA. You need to evaluate this based more on your doubling time and PSA velocity. If you have a doubling time under a year, you need to act on this, ASAP. Best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Dad just diagnosed

Posts.Content: gfr1n51, I probably should not have used the term "quite common" but it does occur. My brother in law has occasional hematuria nearly a decade after radiation for PCa. His RO has attributed it to radiation damage. I myself haven't had a problem...yet, but I'm not even half done with my treatments. The links below deal primarily with radiation proctitis but you may find some useful information there. Bottom line: newporter and I agree that you need to meet with your RO ASAP. --- Dave http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11012447 http://www.ro-journal.com/content/7/1/87 http://www.iffgd.org/site/gi-disorde...diation-injury http://radiology.rsna.org/content/217/1/215.full http://www.oncolink.org/experts/article.cfm?id=2589

Posts.Title: Radiation Damage

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BigT today i am at 3 months post radiation treatment(39) for prostrate cancer. i was expecting to go back to normal within 2 to four weeks as i was assured by my cancer doctor. i never started feeling better at all. i experienced dizziness, shortness of breath, no energy, tiring too easy, and plenty of anxiety. i visited my urologist and primary doctor, who recommended i see my cardiologist where it was determined that i have an irregular heartbeat. Hi BigT, You don't mention whether your radiation was adjuvant or your primary therapy. I strongly suspect that you had an episode of AFIB (atrial fibrillation) which is extremely common after abdominal or thoracic surgery. If radiation was your primary treatment, then your AFIB was most likely due to something else. The symptoms you describe (other than lack of energy) are typical of AFIB. I am curious to know if you doctor prescribed any medications for it and if so, what they were. Lastly, can you please tell us exactly what type of radiotherapy you had? Best of luck!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee One word... thong. Okay, J/K. Anyway, I've been a boxer brief kind of guy for over a decade, but after the RP healed up I went to wearing snug briefs. Some sag as bad as boxer briefs but the bikini style is more snug fitting. Rob, Are you talking so-called 'whitie-tighties or a real thong? I'm at the end of my rope trying to find something that I can use with a pad and will stay up around my hips when they begin to get heavy. As I mentioned in a previous post, I finally resorted to suspenders. Works but a little uncomfortable.

Posts.Title: First post - stage 4 metastatic prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tintomatoes Sorry but this is not a fact. You can survive and reduc prostate cancer with ONLY diet and lifestyle changes - medical fact! And curcumin happens to be a very effective agent in but not well absorbed so I would take a extract ideally mixed with Phosphatidylcholine like the famous brand but you dont need to buy that brand as many others have made the mix much cheaper - pm me if you need more info For dosage of curcumin ref / tintomatoes, I have to totally agree with Fairwind on this one. There are NO peer reviewed studies from accredited sources that show that cancer of any type can be cured or controlled by diet modification alone. To state this as fact is to give false hope. A word of advice, your post comes close to a sales pitch in my opinion and that is generally frowned on here. There IS a forum here which is devoted to alternative therapies. I suggest you try posting there.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with questions about nutrition

Posts.Content: Hi Rob, I certainly know what you're feeling. I had radiation proctitis which is more confined to the rectum itself. Your Doc is right, it will improve with time. Are you having any bleeding? Did your Doc mention how much and what part of your colon was involved? This is, unfortunately, quite common especially in men who fail to retain a full bladder during treatments. Six months isn't very far out and you should probably consider a relatively bland diet, at least for another six months. Good luck with this! --- Dave

Posts.Title: More 'good' news, Radiation Colitis

Posts.Content: Hi Lovell, Welcome to the board. With a PSA of 2.7, as opposed to 27, I'm a little surprised they found that much involvement. If you could provide a little more detail on the biopsy report, we might be able to provide more info. When was his PSA before this one and when? What was the percentage of tumor in the ten cores? Has he had any symptoms? Did the report mention the stage? As to the bone and CT scans, They will almost definitely be negative. (<1%) They are being done as a baseline reference. That being said, clear scans at this point do NOT completely rule out some degree of spread. It is, however, very unlikely especially with a PSA that low. Keep us informed and good luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Dad has PC...

Posts.Content: Hi Lovell, Welcome to the board. With a PSA of 2.7, as opposed to 27, I'm a little surprised they found that much involvement. If you could provide a little more detail on the biopsy report, we might be able to provide more info. When was his PSA before this one and when? What was the percentage of tumor in the ten cores? Has he had any symptoms? Did the report mention the stage? As to the bone and CT scans, They will almost definitely be negative. (<1%) They are being done as a baseline reference. That being said, clear scans at this point do NOT completely rule out some degree of spread. It is, however, very unlikely especially with a PSA that low. Keep us informed and good luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Thinking of passing on salvage radiation.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by blank newporter I know that Walsh give the number 300 in the most recent edition of his book but the studies I have seen were talking "1000" as the number. I wonder what Walsh would say about these studies given the import on patients? blank, I think you're going to find that, like most other stats, these can be confusing. They are only meant as guidelines and are relative to the baseline skills that the surgeon already has. I personally feel that we get too obsessed with specific numbers, the same way we tend to become obsessed with a "famous" doctor, simply because we have seen his stats. It all boils down to the fact that one surgeon may be gifted and extremely prolific at 300 operations while another may take thousands to get it right. Some may never become skilled. This NOT the same as the training minimums that institutions choose to impose on their surgical staff. Those minimums can vary widely for many different reasons and, as far as I know, there is still no formal standardization for training. I feel, as some others here do, that you're far better off if you can get access to your prospective surgeon's actual track record plus input from medical staff that have had at least a few years working with him/her. Just my two cents. --- Dave

Posts.Title: Started Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Steve2017 My urologist phoned me today with the biopsy results from last week. He said it showed 4 positive areas for PC, up from 1 area found in 2014. My last PSA was 3.4. My primary care physician said the DRE I had in 2014 was what found PC initially even though my PSA was in the high normal range. The current biopsy indicated the same Gleason 6 3+3. My uro said he is not immediately concerned and I could remain on active surveillance or opt to have it removed or radiated. He said they could probably spare nerves on one side and possibly more. I have an appointment next month with him. I told him I am not interested in radiation. My prostate size increased in size from 40 to 50s gram. I'm actually fine with this but will probably be joining the prostate removal club and then, hopefully the zero club. I want to avoid the probability of having to catheterize every time I have to urinate as I grow older. My urologist is at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Boston. I met him once for an evaluation and then the second time when he did the biopsy. So, I don’t have a history with this doctor but when asked, he said he has done 500 robotic surgeries. I haven’t had an opportunity yet to ask how many he has done last week. My main concern is being incontinent. I value any suggestions and any knowledge about robotic surgery at Beth Israel. Age 67 Father, 2 brothers had PC Hi Steve, Please don't take this the wrong way as it is, after all, your life. What I can't seem to get my head around is the fact that you waited three years before taking any action. I DO understand your concerns but what makes you think you would have to catheterize every day? At worst, you might have to wear pads but I have never heard of daily catheterization due to or as a consequence of prostate cancer treatment. I know, everyone seems to subscribe to the idea that G6 cells do not mutate or spread yet I remain skeptical in that regard. Either way, I wish you the very best of luck regardless of the mode of treatment (if any) you ultimately choose. Cheers! --- Dave

Posts.Title: prostate cancer - two doctors, two evaluations

Posts.Content: Hey brownie, Sorry you need to be here but welcome! Would you mind sharing where you have had all your treatments? Have you had any other treatments besides the proposed ADT. I ask because a G6 is usually somewhat indolent and it would be quite a surprise if it had spread, especially given your low PSA. Did you actually have an actual prostate biopsy? It seems unusual to have a LN biopsy without a full prostate workup. Stay with us and we'll see what others have to say. Cheers!

Posts.Content: brownie, You need treatment and you need it now. My advice is to run away from the VA as soon as you can! I don't know your situation but if this option is available to you, by all means, take advantage of it! If it is a realistic option, go to Johns Hopkins, they are one of the best in the world, I wish I had! Whatever you do, DON'T wait! Best of luck! ---Dave

Posts.Title: Those on hormone therapy (ADT) may want to learn more about ADT

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Steve2017 My urologist phoned me today with the biopsy results from last week. He said it showed 4 positive areas for PC, up from 1 area found in 2014. My last PSA was 3.4. My primary care physician said the DRE I had in 2014 was what found PC initially even though my PSA was in the high normal range. The current biopsy indicated the same Gleason 6 3+3. My uro said he is not immediately concerned and I could remain on active surveillance or opt to have it removed or radiated. He said they could probably spare nerves on one side and possibly more. I have an appointment next month with him. I told him I am not interested in radiation. My prostate size increased in size from 40 to 50s gram. I'm actually fine with this but will probably be joining the prostate removal club and then, hopefully the zero club. I want to avoid the probability of having to catheterize every time I have to urinate as I grow older. My urologist is at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Boston. I met him once for an evaluation and then the second time when he did the biopsy. So, I don’t have a history with this doctor but when asked, he said he has done 500 robotic surgeries. I haven’t had an opportunity yet to ask how many he has done last week. My main concern is being incontinent. I value any suggestions and any knowledge about robotic surgery at Beth Israel. Age 67 Father, 2 brothers had PC Hi Steve, Please don't take this the wrong way as it is, after all, your life. What I can't seem to get my head around is the fact that you waited three years before taking any action. I DO understand your concerns but what makes you think you would have to catheterize every day? At worst, you might have to wear pads but I have never heard of daily catheterization due to or as a consequence of prostate cancer treatment. I know, everyone seems to subscribe to the idea that G6 cells do not mutate or spread yet I remain skeptical in that regard. Either way, I wish you the very best of luck regardless of the mode of treatment (if any) you ultimately choose. Cheers! --- Dave

Posts.Content: Hi, Are you sure about the PSA of 495? Could it possibly be 4.95? At 495, you almost certainly have advanced metastatic prostate cancer. At this point surgery is almost NEVER recommended as it would do no good because the disease is now systemic. Please check with you doctor and come back here with more details. Can't offer too much advise at this point. Best of luck!

Posts.Content: Hi Scott, I agree with Southsider regarding the use of the prostate supplement. You are taking a LOT more than the recommended dose which will almost definitely reduce your PSA. Saw Palmetto is frequently used for symptoms of BPH, not Pca. You would do well to stop using 'natural alternatives' There is nothing out there that will do anything for Pca.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mkane09 Actually, it sounds like a somewhat radical version of the Adkins diet. No carbs. BTW, the Adkins diet is recommended for patients undergoing gastric bypass surgery. Interesting..... mkane09 Atkins does work. I was on it when I was diagnosed. I had lost 40+ pounds. Unfortunately, I found them again when I learned I had cancer. The problem docs seem to have with Atkins and prostate cancer is the extremely high fat content. I was at 65%! If I read his post correctly, this gentleman was consuming five dozen eggs a day plus meat and cheese! I can only hope that was an exaggeration. "My diet has been very unconventional eating 20 raw eggs in protein/milk shakes, one medium steak or greasy hamburger, yogurt and cheese for all my meals each day." Atkins would turn over in his grave!

Posts.Title: Blood clots in each of my lungs doctor says they suspect prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kazike About 2 years ago I was treated with radiation for prostate cancer. My PSA has been stable since, but I have been having pain in the pelvic area. It feels like having a ball or obstacle between the legs. I am not able to seat for work for a couple of hours. Most of the time I work standing in front of my PC. For the first 1.5 years the pain was not constant and moderate. Lately the pain is permanent, feeling a burning sensation after weak up in the morning, seating is impossible. Anybody having similar experience? Any recommendations? Thank all for your advice. Hi, I can't say for sure what your issue is but I CAN tell you that I developed radiation induced cystitis 3 years after 35 sessions of IMRT. The radiation wound up burning my bladder resulting in hypervascularization and bleeding. This usually means a trip to the ER for catheterization and continuous bladder irrigation. This is usually not pleasant. Are you passing any blood in your urine? This might be a question to pose to your urologist just to get his input. For the record, I also developed radiation induced proctitis as a result of this. The IMRT was adjuvant therapy for positive margins and the bitch of the thing is my PSA is STILL slowly rising. The reason I commented on this is because of the similarity of the symptoms. I wish you the best of luck with this but I will not kid you. You may be stuck with this for a long time, if not for life. Radiation is the gift that keeps on giving. --- Dave

Posts.Title: Years Of Elevated PSA

Posts.Content: Hi all, Well, in a couple of weeks I get my second Lupron injection! I've been on bicalutamide and leuprolide for almost six months now. No noticeable side effects other than a little fatigue and mental fogginess. Hard to differentiate from my normal self. LOL! I'll get a PSA and a baseline testosterone in a week or so to see if any progress has been made since last June when the PSA was 9.3. I'm still totally asymptomatic, thank goodness! I guess that's a good sign. Interestingly, my bladder bleeding stopped a week after I started bicalutamide and has never recurred. Weird! Glad to say I'm able to get out and about more now, despite the diuretics and diapers. (I am a man of constant peeing) Here's to all my forum brothers and sisters. Stay strong and keep the faith!

Posts.Content: Hey Guys! I just had my RRP On July 16th and am now six days into radiation therapy for positive margins. Even before I started the radiation, I was experiencing frequent pain in the testicles. Wondering if any of you have experienced this. Forgive me for being direct but the sensation is very similar to being a teenage guy with a case of the "Blue Balls"! I am not sexually active...yet, as nothing works. Any ideas? --- Dave

Posts.Title: Testicular Pain After RRP?

Posts.Content: Hi all, Well, in a couple of weeks I get my second Lupron injection! I've been on bicalutamide and leuprolide for almost six months now. No noticeable side effects other than a little fatigue and mental fogginess. Hard to differentiate from my normal self. LOL! I'll get a PSA and a baseline testosterone in a week or so to see if any progress has been made since last June when the PSA was 9.3. I'm still totally asymptomatic, thank goodness! I guess that's a good sign. Interestingly, my bladder bleeding stopped a week after I started bicalutamide and has never recurred. Weird! Glad to say I'm able to get out and about more now, despite the diuretics and diapers. (I am a man of constant peeing) Here's to all my forum brothers and sisters. Stay strong and keep the faith!

Posts.Title: Great news

Posts.Content: While it is medically proven that medical marijuana, CBD oil etc. can and do have beneficial effects the certain types of pain and some of the side effects of chemo, there in no empirical scientific evidence whatsoever that it 'kills' cancer cells. We need to understand that when we read reports of 'research' showing evidence to the contrary, these studies are done in a petrie dish in somebody's lab, not in a living organism. Virtually everything kills cancer cells in a lab environment. Hope that helps!

Posts.Title: Diet and Alternative Medicine

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about your relative. I'm sure he was told that he had nerve compression due to fracture and/or erosion of the lumbar spine do to tumor involvement. This is suggestive of advanced disease, (T4) Is there a reason that you're not discussing his case directly with his doctors? They are far more qualified to speculate on his prognosis than anyone here. If you could provide more details as to his stage & grade, what treatments he has had since he was diagnosed, and his age and general state of health, we might be able to offer a little more insight. Best of luck!

Posts.Title: Discovery of gene family that suppress prostate cancer (MNT Article)

Posts.Content: Hi All, Has anyone in the forum community had any experience dealing with healthcare providers when one needs treatment and has no insurance and is on an extremely limited budget? I am almost certainly going to need both Casodex and Lupron within the next few months as my PSA is soaring and my current health insurance ends January 1st with no renewal option. I'm hearing that Lupron runs at least $2,000/dose and that's what my wife and I get for social security every month. I now have other medical issues that basically make me 100% disabled so I can no longer work. I can make very small monthly payments but that's about it. I'm looking for a bit of education from people who have actually been in this position. I just don't feel ready to lay down and die! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Going To Need ADT But Can't Pay

Posts.Content: Hi, How long have you had this condition? You don't mention what kind of doctor you're seeing. Is it a GP or an experienced urologist? What do you mean by "a PSA that is back down 10"? What is the highest it's been? Keep in mind that while a positive attitude is a wonderful thing, it DOES NOT cure cancer! I'm not trying to be a fear monger here but you definitely need to act on this ASAP. I'm just trying to understand why nothing has been done for you if you have a known mass on your prostate!? Best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Content: LL Fauntleroy, As newportersaid, perineural invasion does NOT mean cancer has escaped the prostate. PI is VERY common. As previously stated, your surgeon should be able to answer any questions. It is a very scary term which usually means nothing in the big picture. Have a great holiday! --- Dave

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by fishinguy Thanks all. I hadn't originally planned for a second opinion. I've decided this weekend to do just that. My urologist, who has performed over 3000 open surgeries had talked about it right away, and reminded me that this s about me and not him. I like him, and trust him. But I think I may go to Mayo and have a talk with someone there. Funny, almost makes me feel like I'm cheating on a girlfriend going somewhere else. Anyone else ever had that feeling going for a second opinion? --Dan Unless your urologist is a woman and you are in a relationship with her, then no, it's not cheating.

Posts.Title: First post, Just got the news......

Posts.Content: Hi folks, Thanks so much for the information you provided. I will need to coordinate my efforts with my RO which I am currently in the process of doing. I just found out about the generic equivalents for Lupron and Casodex. That was a big relief! As far as hospital and provider charges go, I'm glad to say that so far, we are holding our own thanks to debt forgiveness on their part. The big issue right now is finding new insurance that I can afford. Here in Arizona, I have only one choice through the AHA and that company only offers four plans. I'll report back when I get some of my ducks in a row. -- Dave

Posts.Title: Another Study Links Testosterone Therapy to MI Risk

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster22 From my experience.........lube the tip of the catheter at the end of your Johnson. You can even pull out the catheter tube about a quarter inch or so. When pulled out, lube the tube, then push it back inside your Johnson to better lube yourself. That is far better then just lubbing the very tip of your Johnson. Any time you feel a need, lube the catheter as much and as often as you like. If you change catheter bags, I found it far better to use the small travel bag during all waking hours. I wore shorts, so the catheter empty control valve would just barely stick out the bottom of the shorts. This made it very easy to empty urine, and a lot easier then carrying a bucket around the neighborhood. I did both approaches, and found the small bag much easier to manage. When transferring from small bag to large bag, I found it easier to do so in the bath tub. Any urine spills were much easier to clean up in the bath tub, as opposed to bathroom hard wood floor or carpet. If you are sleeping in a bed alone as I do, I found it better to lay the catheter collection bag on the bed beside me. I used a rubberized mattress cover, so any urine spill would not soak into the mattress. I never had a spill, and found the extra length of the drain tube gave me much more freedom to lay different ways in bed, particularly being able to sleep on my side. I used extra pillows placed on both sides of my body to keep from rolling over or around too much in the bed. Overall this is a much better experience, then hooking the collection bag to the side of the bed rail, or laying it on the floor. It does not allow much body movement in bed. I had to wear a Foley catheter for a total of 21 days over two episodes, so during that time, I had plenty of time to experiment to see what wearing improvements I could find to make Foley catheter life just a little better and easier. Hope some of these ideas help you and others. Get well soon...........Rooster Great advice from all, as usual. Just a caution on sleeping with the night bag on the bed with you. If you don't have the bag lower than your bladder, it is possible to either roll over on the bag or have the contents siphon back into your bladder by gravity. Either way, it can set you up with a UTI. Been there, done it! Best of luck!

Posts.Content: I saw some reports that said 100% of PSA's over 20 were metastasised. Ugh, that's my main worry now. Hi William, Is it possible you might have misread the reports? It is generally accepted that a PSA over 100 indicates systemic disease however a PSA of 20 could be caused by a number of things, including infection. It IS true that, in the presence of PCa, the higher the PSA and the lower the free PSA, the worse the long term prognosis. That DOES NOT mean an automatic death sentence! Keep us posted and good luck! --- Dave

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago Here is a good site. Seems to not be that complicated. http://www.healthcentral.com/drdean/408/81106.html My favorite line... "How you reach the prostate, of course, is up to you" ( Is there more than one route?) First of all: that article was posted a decade ago! Second: Dean Edell is an ophthalmologist so where he gets his expertise on rectal exams is beyond me. Third, As I stated before, there is NO WAY that an individual can perform his own DRE correctly, primarily due to obvious anatomical restrictions. Fourth: Even if it WAS physically possible to do an adaquate exam on yourself, the average Joe is unlikely to have the training and experience to interpret the findings with any accuracy. Even some otherwise competent physicians don't do them as well as they should! For what it's worth, around the time that was published, there was also a popular rumor that women could do their own PAP smears. That one also bit the dust for many of the same reasons!

Posts.Title: cancer vs inflamed/infected prostate

Posts.Content: Bassman1956 My personal opinion is that either your first biopsy was misread and was in fact, negative or, your latest one missed the malignant area(s) which actually happens quite often. You do not mention your PSA values. If you can, provide more detail about your biopsies and lab values, we may be able to offer more insight. As far as nutrition or level of fitness etc. curing existing cancer, there is currently no credible evidence to support that. Best of luck! --- Dave

As far as nutrition or level of fitness etc. curing existing cancer, there is currently no credible evidence to support that. Best of luck! --- Dave
