Posts.Title: cancer vs inflamed/infected prostate

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bigalcalbisque Please look at my Biopsy results on my profile. I am currently in a state of semi-confusion in regards to what direction to take (Prostate Removal Or Radiation) Have had a consultation with both Urologist and Radiologist. Neither one was trying to sell me on their remedies. So I don't feel any pressure in that regard. My #1 major concern would be what will help me live the longest. I have been married for 36 years and basically don't have a sexual relationship. We are more like Partners/ Great Friends. If I need to release the pressure valve I take the situation in hand. So all sarcasm aside. It's not a priority even though it would be nice to have the "ability" in case things change. its a 2 on my scale. Having an occasional leakage problem would also be a #2 on my scale. I like to fish, so casting and getting a little leakage wouldn't be an issue, even though my heartless buddies would capitalize on it if they saw a wet spot on my Levi's (Sarcasm). Rectal incontinence would be a 9 or 10 on my scale for obvious reasons. I do have Moderate Diverticulosis and have it totally under control with my diet, no flare-ups in a year and a half. Not sure the implications of that on my final decision. Both my Urologist and my Radiologist are letting me take a fishing trip with my buddies Sept 11-16-2017 before any procedures, so I am assuming that is an indication of the seriousness or lack of seriousness of my situation. However I want to decide on my direction before that and set up the appropriate appointments. Also, would you recommend any scans on my bones or other areas before I proceed? Comments would be greatly appreciated. Thank you everyone for your support! Al Hi bigalcalbisque, Love your description of yourself, you sound just like me! Based on your posted stats, you could probably go either way with with your choice of treatment with equally good results. That being said, as you are a 4+3 vs a 3+4, you might want to consider surgery as opposed to radiation because with surgery, you will have the added benefit of knowing precisely what your tumor status was which you will not have with radiation. A 4+3 can be significantly more aggressive than a 3+4 and the pathologist will upgrade or downgrade based on the cut samples. This is much more accurate than a biopsy alone. Best of luck! --- Dave

I was laid off five to six months ago, and since then I have been trying to focus my efforts in securing a new position since then. During this time I could not follow up with my PCP or my urologist. I had a scheduled appointment with my urologist and I let him know my PSA just taken. I have not heard back from him, but I guess he will let me know what to do next. I do hope everyone I corresponded with is doing well, and do hope I can hear back from you guys. Looking forward to hearing from everyone. See you soon! RobP Hi Rob and welcome back! Life gets in the way sometimes. Keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Blood in urine

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Featherboy: I respectfully disagree with the logic of sticking one's head in the sand and ignoring the growth in what is called "undetectable" PSA results. As you can see from my history, it was the ultra sensitive PSA tests that alerted me to the return of my cancer and I was not surprised once the 0.1 reading was exceeded. It helped to prepare me with the fortitude to fight PC yet a second time. I think it would have been more traumatic if I had embraced the <0.1 readings and believed that I was in no danger. Jim Jim, I don't believe I ever advocated "sticking one's head in the sand". I merely emphasized the point that there ia a great deal of controversy over the ultrasensitive PSA assays. As Highlander has repeatedly pointed out, even the world renown Mayo Clinic doesn't use it for that very reason. There is currently no empirical evidence that outcomes are any different regardless of which assay one chooses to use. I was merely saying that, based on his stats, I'm not convinced that he has an upward trend at all! These, of course, are issues that he should discuss with his medical team. PS: Your case and his are not the same. No two cases are alike.

Posts.Title: 2 months post-op (new member) w/testicle pain

Posts.Content: Hi rooster, I agree with the others in that it would be helpful to have additional pathology information. Positive margins DO NOT automatically mean metastases. However, if untreated, it is possible that they might contribute to it years down the road. His G7 (4+3) is moderately aggressive and adjuvant radiation to the prostatic fossa (bed) is commonly used in cases like this with excellent results and generally few side affects. In fact, I'm currently going through it myself. I AM curious about why they decided to include hormone therapy along with the radiation with such a low PSA. To me, it seems like overkill because hormone therapy in one of your "big guns" that you generally reserve for later, if and when you need it. In any case, I'm sure your father will have many more years to enjoy symptom free. Good luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Positive margins and PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Featherboy: I respectfully disagree with the logic of sticking one's head in the sand and ignoring the growth in what is called "undetectable" PSA results. As you can see from my history, it was the ultra sensitive PSA tests that alerted me to the return of my cancer and I was not surprised once the 0.1 reading was exceeded. It helped to prepare me with the fortitude to fight PC yet a second time. I think it would have been more traumatic if I had embraced the <0.1 readings and believed that I was in no danger. Jim Jim, I don't believe I ever advocated "sticking one's head in the sand". I merely emphasized the point that there ia a great deal of controversy over the ultrasensitive PSA assays. As Highlander has repeatedly pointed out, even the world renown Mayo Clinic doesn't use it for that very reason. There is currently no empirical evidence that outcomes are any different regardless of which assay one chooses to use. I was merely saying that, based on his stats, I'm not convinced that he has an upward trend at all! These, of course, are issues that he should discuss with his medical team. PS: Your case and his are not the same. No two cases are alike.

Posts.Title: Hi all First post

Posts.Content: Hawk, I my humble opinion, you would be better off NOT using the ultrasensitive tests. Just stick to the gold standard. The values in the ultrasensitive assays fluctuate all the time and usually mean nothing. What we look for is an upward trend over time. If you look at your values, you will find that they ALL round off to 0.1 which is considered undetectable. In some labs, even 0.2 falls within that range. There is a HUGE amount of conflicting information out there which is extremely difficult for the average layman to sort through. I encourage you to speak with your medical team regarding this. Good luck and above all, don't panic! -- Dave

Posts.Title: 6 week follow up after RALP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH It is a somber thought when realizing that the internal sphincter (in the bladder) is removed along with the urethra -- and the opening created by this process must be "rebuilt" down to the diameter of the reattached urethra. This is probably where some patients have continence problems and perhaps this is where some surgeons "get away" with doing a poor reconstruction job and thereby cause urination problems. Hi Chuck, It is my understanding that we actually have TWO urethral sphincters, an upper and a lower. The lower one is always removed however the upper, which is part of the bladder is only removed if there is evidence of disease in that area. The cut end of the urethra is simply sutured onto the upper sphincter. The urinary issues usually come into play due to scarring, shortening of the urethra itself and problems with the suture line at the bladder neck, e.g. scarring, leakage etc.

Posts.Title: Stress starting to build

Posts.Content: Hi folks, This is the latest update since August, 2015. I really wish I could say all is well but that is not the case. Since the end of the IMRT treatments in 2012, everything has been ok in the sense that there have been no catastrophic issues to deal with. In July,2015, I began to notice blood spotting in my urine. Went to my primary Doc who thought it might just be a UTI. Things went well for a couple of weeks till one morning, I went to void my bladder and it was pure blood! In an effort to avoid writing a large book about what happened during the next year, I am going to just give the facts with short commentary. Turns out, I have radiation induced hemorrhagic cystitis. It appears that during treatment, the beam took a little more than intended and the bladder lining was essentially "burned". This resulted in the formation of new blood vessels in the bladder lining which are extremely delicate and tend to bleed if disturbed at all. This issue wound up requiring two separate surgeries, a week apart to control. Quite honestly, it was pure hell for awhile. I still have occasional spotting if the perineal area receives any significant pressure e.g. bike riding. To make matters worse, the cancer is back. PSA was fairly stable for nearly three years. My last test, around a month ago revealed that it doubled in three months. 0.8 to 1.8. Not good. If, in fact this is a true trend, we will probably start ADT in the form of Casodex first for a month or so and then begin Lupron. I am not looking forward to that! At this point, we do not know where the cancer is located and it is way too early for scans. Am I scared? I guess, a little bit but I have at least two other potentially life threatining conditions running concurrently and the cancer is the least formidable of them. Now, the answer to the big question. If I had to go through all of this again, would I change anything? Actually, very little. Please bear in mind that my case is somewhat atypical and most prostate cancer patients will never go through this nonsense. What I might do differently would be to use radiotherapy in the form of Brachytherapy (seeds). Surgery, in my case, was not curative and I was left 100% impotent as well as 100% urinary incontinent. With brachy, you don't have issues like positive margins which seems to be what got me. Most importantly, make sure you know and understand all your options when you are diagnosed. I moved far to quickly out of fear. Even if it is a highly aggressive tumor, it is not going to kill you today, or next week or even next month. Taking one's time, within reason, can avoid a lot of unwanted side effects. I honestly have no clue what my future holds. I just play it a day at a time. Cheers to all the members of our unique club! -- Dave Robbins

Posts.Content: Hi Ernest, The cancer may be unique to each man but the anxiety is not. We all go through that so rest assured, you're in good company. The good news is that your PSA values are literally meaningless when taken in context. You are totally in the 'zero club' and there is no sign of a trend in either direction so trust your doctor on that. As far as the MO, they are usually not involved until the disease is systemic which yours is almost definitely not. So relax and enjoy life because you've got a lot of it yet to live. Cheers! --- Dave

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gimmy Hi guys , doctor wants me on zytiga 250mg starting Monday .should I do it ? My son is going nuts over this up to now he's made all the right calls .but this zytiga seems to only be used for extending life for 2-5 months or there abouts. so he thinks if he says no he'll be killing me early and if he says yes then he's afraid I'll suffer more. There's too much going on for me to think straight........anyone else using it....Thanks Eugene Hi Eugene, Even though there is a lot going on in your life right now, you still have your own mind and your own wishes regarding your future. You need to pay attention to them. No one here can make the decision as to whether you SHOULD take a course of action regarding your illness. Neither can your family. Rich S is absolutely correct in that 2-5 months is not cut in stone. Whether you take this path is a matter of personal preference and you would probably do well to "absolve" your son of his perceived responsibility to you. Doing so might well make the remaining time you have together more rewarding for both of you. Something to consider. I can only imagine how difficult this is for you and I wish you the best outcome possible! Take care. --- Dave

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Replicant Even men who suffer devastating side effects from prostatecomies can have sex. Half the world's population has sex, and orgasms, without a single erection or even a penis. Orgasms happen mainly in the brain. So I wouldn't fret that you run the risk of "never having sex again" but it's rational to worry about whether or not you will have erections. Again, at 44 with relatively low risk cancer--if you find the right surgeon, you'll probably be able to function normally again (except there won't be semen any more) and you might have to use a medication or other ED treatment to be completely like you were before. This is very true and and frankly, one of the most intelligent and insightful posts I have seen since I joined this group. Bravo, Replicant!

Posts.Title: PSA Velocity Does Not Enhance Prognostic Value of PCa Screening

Posts.Content: judway, Prostate 5LX is is just another saw palmetto product designed to be used for relief of benign conditions of the prostate. There is a sadly misunderstood notion out there that any treatment that reduces PSA is also treating the cancer. This is not the case. There is no empirical evidence out there that I am aware of that proves that such products do any more than relieve symptoms, mostly by relieving inflammation. PSA values are virtually useless when using such products. PS: That being said, I see you are using the ultra sensitive assay. Your last test translates to 0.9 from 0.2 back in 2006. This is an EXTREMELY slow rise. Always make sure you're using the same lab and the same assay for all testing. Also make sure there is no stimulation of the prostate e.g. DRE, sex of any kind, bike riding etc. within 48 hours of your exam. I feel confident in telling you that at this stage of your life, PCa is NOT an issue you need to dwell on. If you still have concerns, please talk to your Urologist. All the best!

Posts.Content: 35coupe, I'm quite sure most of the others here will agree that the short answer is that PSA values are far and away more valuable AFTER the fact. The controversy is more about when or even whether to rely on it for initial diagnosis. Levels are hard to interpret and are a guide at best. If you have no prostate, or it has been killed by radiation, then you should have no PSA, period! I hope I haven't confused you. The long answer is a lot more complex! Cheers!

Posts.Title: What am I looking at after 5 1/2 years?

Posts.Content: Hi, The PSA tests are extremely accurate as long as you use the same assay/lab for each test. This is going to be important in your case because your numbers are so low. Generally, 'undetectable' is currently considered to be <0.1 using the standard test. Are you on other treatment protocols that might affect PSA such as hormone therapy? We can be of more help if you can provide your pre and post surgical stats. Salvage radiotherapy makes the assumption that at least a few malignant cells were missed at the time of surgery and are resident either in the prostatic fossa (bed) or the local lymph nodes or both. Based on your PSA, I would HIGHLY doubt that you have systemic disease however I am not qualified to speculate. If you DO have a recurrence, external beam radiotherapy has a very good track record. RT is NOT like it was a few decades ago. I AM qualified to say that as I just finished 35 IMRT treatments myself. It was a breeze! Keep in touch and good luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: PSA Rising, Need Guidance

Posts.Content: Hi, Given the info you provide, I'm guessing that your bladder isn't emptying completely, possibly due to an inflammation of some sort. Is your flow strong? If not you might have some prostatic enlargement or possible scarring as a result of the radiation. Either way, a quick visit to the doctor (urologist) is in order and should put your mind at rest. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Hi Bamboo, You appear to have a biochemical recurrence. Approx. one third of us will experience this within five years according to latest stats. Treatment will depend on where the recurrence is. If you had surgery alone, you may have the option of salvage radiation to the prostatic fossa (bed). If you can provide complete details of your biopsy and post-op pathology, we can expand on this a bit. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Husband just diagnosed-I'm terrified. Please advise if you can

Posts.Content: Hi Mark! I totally concur with Highlander's assessment. It's VERY important to remember that with any form of radiotherapy, the prostate takes a huge hit and is forever changed. The vascular system within it is also damaged which can result in vascular friability which can be extremely unpredictable. I speak from experience as I have a similar issue with my bladder known as Radiation Induced Hemorrhagic Cystitis. It occurred around three years after I was treated. Radiation is a wonderful tool against cancer but it is 'the gift that keeps on giving'. You will undoubtedly be fine but you may have to put up with this nuisance for the rest of your life. A small price for a cancer cure! Best of luck!

Posts.Title: Reclinging Testosterone 18 months AFTER last Lupron? And also Multiple Kidney stones

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman So i finally go to speak with the Uro - first conversation since the biopsy (from my other thread you may know i got the good news that results were negative for cancer via email from the nurse). He told me that 1 sample (i think he took 14, at least thats how many of those little sample containers they wheeled in for the biopsy along with the tools) showed Hi Grade PIN. He explained that it used to be accepted that this was a precursor or hi predictor of future PC diagnosis, but that it is generally not so much universally accepted any more and they (he) believe that it is not necessarily a precursor. But he also said that there are doctors who will disagree. He suggested i not wait a year, retake PSA in 6 months. Well, that was definitive! Any thoughts? Hi Pratoman, From my own research, I believe he is giving you good advice. PIN, high grade or otherwise does not guarantee the subsequent development of cancer, however it is still generally thought to be a fairly reliable predictor. If I were you, I would trust his advice but I'd run the PSAs every three months instead of six. The test is simple and cheap so why not? Good luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Many Unknowns With Surveillance After Cancer Treatment (Medscape)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by maxsmom Hi everyone, I'm new to these forums and I'm hoping someone can give me some piece of mind. My husband was diagnosed with prostate and bone cancer 2 years ago, and his initial PSA was somewhere in the high 20's, but he has been on Lupron as the treatment (he could not complete the chemo, but he did have radiation) and his PSA has always been .01. Now he is due for his next shot in 2 1/2 weeks, and his oncologist called and said his PSA is now .2. Is it starting to climb because the Lupron is almost due? Thank you for any help! Hi maxsmom, When your husband was diagnosed 2 years ago, was it prostate cancer w/bone involvement or did he present with both prostate and actual bone cancer (two different animals)? Can you provide any more information regarding his treatment?

Posts.Title: Aggressive prostate cancer diagnosis from a catheter change?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider 4.7 is just modestly elevated for a man of your age. I wouldn't be terribly worried at all. The PSA test is not specific to prostate cancer, it goes higher as your prostate gets bigger as you get older. The normal prostate for a man who is 20, might be the size of a walnut, it reaches the size of a golf ball at age 40, a lemon at age 60, and a softball at age 80. you definitely want to follow up on this, it certainly might be a false negative, but more likely not. I think that might be stretching it a bit there, South! LOL!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mkane09 Because I had a history of hemorrhoids, I had some pretty severe burning rectally. mkane09 mickcee, Yes, I had mercifully forgotten that part. I too, have internal, bleeding hemorrhoids. As far as the burning, you don't want to go there! It does diminish fairly rapidly after treatment ceases though! Also, keep in mind that the size of the area being irradiated will affect the degree and intensity of side effects. My target area was just the prostatic fossa (bed) and that is quite small. If you had the whole pelvis irradiated, you could reasonably expect more issues. --- Dave

Posts.Title: 16 months Post OP, I give up

Posts.Content: Hi kinghorne, Welcome and sorry you need to be here! Because of the presence of G4 cells in your biopsy, you are probably not a good candidate for "watchful waiting" and/or "active surveillance". You will get numerous opinions as there is a great deal of collective experience here. Personally, I favor early surgery (the earlier the better) assuming you are in fairly good health in general. IMRT can also be a good option, especially nowadays but both can have significant side effects. Brachytherapy (seeds) are another option. It depends a lot on what your expectations regarding continence, sexual health etc. are. You need to have a long, face to face discussion with your urologist/surgeon regarding your options. From your stats, you appear to be getting on this quite early and most likely have an excellent chance at a long, healthy life. Good luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Diagnosed prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wolfgang While the above is true, the Saw Palmetto does not reduce the PSA levels. I was taking high dose Saw Palmetto 1000 mg capsules for about 3 years and while my BPH symptoms were mild, my PSA level tripled in that period of time. It certainly shrunk the gland which was verified by the urologist who performed the first TRUS (unfortunately false negative) biopsies. I then realized it was about time to get saturation biopsy to detect the suspecting cancer in my prostate. Wolfgang, With a G9 cancer, I'm sure your PSA values would have been MUCH higher without the Saw Palmetto. It is common knowledge that it reduces inflammation and thereby PSA. That doesn't justify it's use in cases of suspected but yet unproven cases of Pca.

Posts.Title: Dr. Charles "Snuffy" Myers

Posts.Content: Hi Julie, So sorry to hear that! I don't have personal experience with HT (as yet) but I do know depression is a very common side effect in some people. He probably should bring this up to his medical team as there are many medications that can effectively remedy these symptoms. As to the fatigue, the radiation is probably the culprit here. I was VERY tired for no apparent reason around my 4th or 5th week. Rest assured it will pass when he finishes therapy. I'm sure folks with more experience with HT will offer their comments soon. Best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: PSA Rising, Need Guidance

Posts.Content: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proton_therapy The types of treatments for which protons are used can be separated into two broad categories. The first are those for disease sites that favor the delivery of higher doses of radiation, i.e. dose escalation. In some instances dose escalation has been shown to achieve a higher probability of "cure" (i.e. local control) than conventional radiotherapy.[11] These include (but are not limited to) uveal melanoma (ocular tumors), skull base and paraspinal tumors (chondrosarcoma and chordoma), and unresectable sarcomas. In all these cases proton therapy achieves significant improvements in the probability of local control over conventional radiotherapy.[12][13][14] The second broad class are those treatments where the increased precision of proton therapy is used to reduce unwanted side effects, by limiting the dose to normal tissue. In these cases the tumor dose is the same as that used in conventional therapy, and thus there is no expectation of an increased probability of curing the disease. Instead, the emphasis is on the reduction of the integral dose to normal tissue, and thus a reduction of unwanted effects.[11] Two prominent examples are pediatric neoplasms (such as medulloblastoma) and prostate cancer. In the case of pediatric treatments there is convincing clinical data showing the advantage of sparing developing organs by using protons, and the resulting reduction of long term damage to the surviving child.[15][16] In the case of prostate cancer the issue is not so clear. Some published studies found a reduction in long term rectal and genitio-urinary damage when treating with protons rather than photons (also known as X-ray or gamma ray therapy). Others showed the difference is small, and limited to cases where the prostate is particularly close to certain anatomical structures.[17][18] The relatively small improvement found may be the result of inconsistent patient set-up and internal organ movement during treatment, which offsets most of the advantage due to increased precision.[18][19][19][20] One source suggests that dose errors around 20% can result from motion errors of just 2.5 mm,[citation needed] and another that prostate motion is between 510 mm.[21] However, the number of cases of prostate cancer diagnosed each year far exceeds those of the other diseases referred to above, and this has led some, but not all, facilities to devote a majority of their treatments slots to prostate treatments. For example two hospital facilities devote roughly 65%[22] and 50%[23] of their proton treatment capacity to prostate cancer, while a third devotes only 7.1%[24] Current overall world wide numbers are hard to compile, but one example in the literature shows that in 2003 roughly 26% of proton therapy treatments world wide were for prostate cancer.[25] Proton therapy for ocular (eye) tumors is a special case since this treatment requires only a comparatively low energy (about 70 MeV). Owing to this low energy requirement, some particle therapy centers only treat ocular tumors.[8] Proton, or more generally, hadron therapy of tissue close to the eye affords sophisticated methods to assess the alignment of the eye that can vary significantly from other patient position verification approaches in image guided particle therapy.[26] Position verification and correction have to ensure that sensitive tissue like the optic nerve is spared from the radiation in order to preserve the patients vision. Comparison with other treatment options[edit source | editbeta] The issue of when, whether, and how best to apply this technology is controversial.[27][28][29] As of 2012 there have been no controlled trials to demonstrate that proton therapy yields improved survival, or other clinical outcomes (including impotence in prostate cancer) compared to other types of radiation therapy, although a 5-year study of prostate cancer is underway at Massachusetts General Hospital.[30][31][32][33][33] Proton therapy is far more expensive than conventional therapy.[28][34] Using current technology, proton therapy requires a very large capital investment (from $100M to more than $180M).[27][29][35] Preliminary results from a three-year 2009 study, including high dose treatments, show very few side effects.[36]

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I wonder if T is dangerous to a man whose prostate has been removed. If all of the cancer was removed along with it, I'm guessing that T would be okay? But if any PC cells remain, perhaps the presence of T would jumpstart it into growing faster? Chuck, You're absolutely right. That WOULD be fine in a perfect world, but as we all know, there is currently no technology that can positively rule out the possibility, no matter how small, that some malignant cells remain. Therefore I tend to think that it should be avoided even after as much as 2 decades of undetectable PSA.

Posts.Title: UCSF Study: Diets Do Reduce Prostate Cancer Death

Posts.Content: 35coupe, I'm quite sure most of the others here will agree that the short answer is that PSA values are far and away more valuable AFTER the fact. The controversy is more about when or even whether to rely on it for initial diagnosis. Levels are hard to interpret and are a guide at best. If you have no prostate, or it has been killed by radiation, then you should have no PSA, period! I hope I haven't confused you. The long answer is a lot more complex! Cheers!

Posts.Title: Husband is post robotic surgery, pathology report not so good

Posts.Content: Hi mickcee, I'm not commenting on the nosebleeds without knowing what medicines you take, what climate you live in and your general health as a whole. As far as adjuvant/salvage radiation goes, I can speak from experience. I your case, you would doubtless be receiving a course of IMRT (Intensity Modulated Radiation Therapy). Nowadays, radiation is MUCH more accurate than even a decade ago. The number of weeks and the total dose will depend on your specific needs. I had 35 treatments over 7 weeks for a total dose of 80 Gy. Side effects were almost non-existent until around the 5th week when I started experiencing significant fatigue. Toward the end of treatment, I was having what I would call, "minor" urinary and fecal incontinence more from urgency than anything else. Now, several months after the last treatment, I STILL have bouts of diarrhea and fecal urgency. They are much improved over what they were but there is a chance I will have to live with at least a certain degree of this. A lot of it depends on the experience and skill of your RO in developing your personal treatment plan. Your treatment team should be meeting with you at least weekly to evaluate your progress and side effects. Best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Poll - When do you leak

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider 4.7 is just modestly elevated for a man of your age. I wouldn't be terribly worried at all. The PSA test is not specific to prostate cancer, it goes higher as your prostate gets bigger as you get older. The normal prostate for a man who is 20, might be the size of a walnut, it reaches the size of a golf ball at age 40, a lemon at age 60, and a softball at age 80. you definitely want to follow up on this, it certainly might be a false negative, but more likely not. I think that might be stretching it a bit there, South! LOL!

Posts.Title: Now I'm Getting A Little Nervous!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Welcome. Sorry you need to be here! Are you quite sure about the PSA values? Those scores ( 147/103) are VERY high. Are you sure there isn't a decimal missing? Were the G7s 3+4 or 4+3? It the PSA values ARE correct, your husband most likely has at least some metastatic spread. If that is the case, surgery would most likely be ruled out as an option. The stage somewhat surprises me also. I would STRONGLY recommend that you make an appointment with a competent medical oncologist as soon as possible to discuss the possibility of starting hormone therapy (ADT). Please check your stats and give us an update. Best of luck! Hello, I unintentionally gave you totally unsolicited advice last night and I apologize. I was not paying attention and thought your post was the original in this thread. Apparently it is not possible to delete one's own posts on this forum so that's why it's still there. I may be an idiot but at least I have good intentions!

Posts.Content: Guys, This is a great thread because it speaks of a way of coping that many cancer patients may deny. Being almost totally preoccupied with your state of health is not only normal but necessary. We can and must be our own advocates. We should not be concerned with a preoccupation with 'me'. Our health becomes our full-time job and the more we have wrong with us, the more difficult it becomes. My comment here is in total support of the previous posts in this thread because it accurately reflects my own case. It was very comforting to see that others go through exactly the same thing. Keep the faith! --- Dave

Posts.Title: With apologies....

Posts.Content: I totally agree with Fairwind on this. As difficult as it is to accept, your father cannot win the battle at this stage, but he DOES NOT have to spend what remaining time he has suffering. Do not let anyone tell you otherwise. I suggest that you consider switching your priorities and concentrate on helping him be as comfortable as possible. Your palliative care team is the place to start. We know how hard this is for you and we are here if you need us. Good luck! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Checking In

Posts.Content: Hi all and thanks for the great input! Just got done with the uro appt. He spent a lot of time with us and was encouraging but he agreed it is time to act. He wants to start with a full body bone scan which I will have on the 8th. Based on those results, we will then look into more sophisticated imaging. He is a little frustrated because, as always, he has to go "toe to toe" with the insurance to get this stuff authorized. If the bone scan is positive, we will initiate ADT. Casodex followed by Lupron. If it is negative, we will have to make the decision of whether to start ADT anyway or to watch the PSA a little longer. I imagine this is where the MO comes in. I flat out forgot to ask him if he felt it was time to bring one in! The options that Michael F mentioned regarding more types of scans are all on the table as far as he is concerned. it is just a matter of getting them paid for. So until I know more, I'll just join Brother Prato in some bourbon and a Xanax. Cheers!

Posts.Title: Now I'm Getting A Little Nervous!

Posts.Content: For nearly the past five years since my diagnoses and subsequent surgery and IMRT, I've been sort of basking in the glow of 'pseudo confidence'. I knew my PSA was rising (I haven't been in the 'Zero Club' for years), but the climb has been intermittent and really slow. Six months ago, it reached an all-time high of 1.8 and three months later dropped to 1.6. We were all happy. I just got my latest results back and it is now 7.3! It has doubled nearly 2.5 times in three months! Needless to say, I have made an appointment with my Uro but the earliest I could get was June 1st. (he's probably out of town on another golf trip!) Of all the posters on this forum, I am one of the least experienced with this crap. Given my stats and what you folks know about me, what do you think should be the next step? Got a little 'sticker shock' here! Am I in deep tapioca? --- Dave

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Welcome. Sorry you need to be here! Are you quite sure about the PSA values? Those scores ( 147/103) are VERY high. Are you sure there isn't a decimal missing? Were the G7s 3+4 or 4+3? It the PSA values ARE correct, your husband most likely has at least some metastatic spread. If that is the case, surgery would most likely be ruled out as an option. The stage somewhat surprises me also. I would STRONGLY recommend that you make an appointment with a competent medical oncologist as soon as possible to discuss the possibility of starting hormone therapy (ADT). Please check your stats and give us an update. Best of luck! Hello, I unintentionally gave you totally unsolicited advice last night and I apologize. I was not paying attention and thought your post was the original in this thread. Apparently it is not possible to delete one's own posts on this forum so that's why it's still there. I may be an idiot but at least I have good intentions!

Posts.Content: Guys, This is a great thread because it speaks of a way of coping that many cancer patients may deny. Being almost totally preoccupied with your state of health is not only normal but necessary. We can and must be our own advocates. We should not be concerned with a preoccupation with 'me'. Our health becomes our full-time job and the more we have wrong with us, the more difficult it becomes. My comment here is in total support of the previous posts in this thread because it accurately reflects my own case. It was very comforting to see that others go through exactly the same thing. Keep the faith! --- Dave

Posts.Title: Now I'm Getting A Little Nervous!

Posts.Content: Hi all and thanks for the great input! Just got done with the uro appt. He spent a lot of time with us and was encouraging but he agreed it is time to act. He wants to start with a full body bone scan which I will have on the 8th. Based on those results, we will then look into more sophisticated imaging. He is a little frustrated because, as always, he has to go "toe to toe" with the insurance to get this stuff authorized. If the bone scan is positive, we will initiate ADT. Casodex followed by Lupron. If it is negative, we will have to make the decision of whether to start ADT anyway or to watch the PSA a little longer. I imagine this is where the MO comes in. I flat out forgot to ask him if he felt it was time to bring one in! The options that Michael F mentioned regarding more types of scans are all on the table as far as he is concerned. it is just a matter of getting them paid for. So until I know more, I'll just join Brother Prato in some bourbon and a Xanax. Cheers!

Posts.Title: Now I'm Getting A Little Nervous!

Posts.Content: For nearly the past five years since my diagnoses and subsequent surgery and IMRT, I've been sort of basking in the glow of 'pseudo confidence'. I knew my PSA was rising (I haven't been in the 'Zero Club' for years), but the climb has been intermittent and really slow. Six months ago, it reached an all-time high of 1.8 and three months later dropped to 1.6. We were all happy. I just got my latest results back and it is now 7.3! It has doubled nearly 2.5 times in three months! Needless to say, I have made an appointment with my Uro but the earliest I could get was June 1st. (he's probably out of town on another golf trip!) Of all the posters on this forum, I am one of the least experienced with this crap. Given my stats and what you folks know about me, what do you think should be the next step? Got a little 'sticker shock' here! Am I in deep tapioca? --- Dave

Posts.Content: Wow! You and I seem to have a lot in common. I feel like I'm reading my own story. Back to you. Obviously, I can't diagnose you but I will say that it really sounds like your bladder is not emptying completely. Did your doc mention whether it was empty when he scoped it? I have similar issue but MUCH less severe and that's what my doc and I chalked it up to...so far. Try to establish an association between the onset of these symptoms three months ago and any change in meds, health, environment or anything else you may consider significant. I realize that my response is a little ambiguous but there are a LOT of things that can cause this. At this point, I would be looking into the medications you're taking and possibly discussing it with a competent pharmacist. Explain that physical/mechanical causes seem to have been ruled out. I really hope you get this resolved soon. Good luck! --- Dave PS: Of course, you could always up the dose of Makers Mark. I'll have one with ya!

Posts.Content: Hi all and thanks for the great input! Just got done with the uro appt. He spent a lot of time with us and was encouraging but he agreed it is time to act. He wants to start with a full body bone scan which I will have on the 8th. Based on those results, we will then look into more sophisticated imaging. He is a little frustrated because, as always, he has to go "toe to toe" with the insurance to get this stuff authorized. If the bone scan is positive, we will initiate ADT. Casodex followed by Lupron. If it is negative, we will have to make the decision of whether to start ADT anyway or to watch the PSA a little longer. I imagine this is where the MO comes in. I flat out forgot to ask him if he felt it was time to bring one in! The options that Michael F mentioned regarding more types of scans are all on the table as far as he is concerned. it is just a matter of getting them paid for. So until I know more, I'll just join Brother Prato in some bourbon and a Xanax. Cheers!

Posts.Title: Cancer back after 13 years?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Welcome. Sorry you need to be here! Are you quite sure about the PSA values? Those scores ( 147/103) are VERY high. Are you sure there isn't a decimal missing? Were the G7s 3+4 or 4+3? It the PSA values ARE correct, your husband most likely has at least some metastatic spread. If that is the case, surgery would most likely be ruled out as an option. The stage somewhat surprises me also. I would STRONGLY recommend that you make an appointment with a competent medical oncologist as soon as possible to discuss the possibility of starting hormone therapy (ADT). Please check your stats and give us an update. Best of luck! Hello, I unintentionally gave you totally unsolicited advice last night and I apologize. I was not paying attention and thought your post was the original in this thread. Apparently it is not possible to delete one's own posts on this forum so that's why it's still there. I may be an idiot but at least I have good intentions!

Posts.Title: Happy National Cancer Survivor's Day!

Posts.Content: I have no issues with the Da Vinci technology however I don't think it's a replacement for years of experience using highly trained, sensitive hands directly in the body. With conventional surgery, the surgeon has access to all his senses. With the robot, he has only his eyes plus a lot more to worry about interfacing with the machine. I would prefer that my surgeon had ALL his attention on ME! Just my two cents.

Posts.Content: Hi, Once in a while, BPH (Benign Prostatic Atrophy) might raise PSA that high but in this case I think your biopsies are missing the mark. Are you in the UK or the USA? Unfortunately, it matters. We need to know as much information about your case as possible to give an educated answer. Others will chip in so don't panic. A quick estimate of your PSA velocity suggests you are not in immediate danger. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Just got the bad news....40 years old

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate I would wait and request a PHI test next time. That offers the same type of "do I need a biopsy?" assessment, but using different markers than 4K. Biopsies are not to be taken lightly. The chances of hospitalization for sepsis are 2 out of 100, and mortality is 1 of 1400. I have had 5 biopsies. Three were non-eventful, and two created long lasting pain and permanent prostate damage. My psa was doubled, and tripled for six months. Did I mention that all were done by professors of Urology at Johns Hopkins? A positive DRE does NOT mean that you have cancer, it means that you could possibly have it, and that more tests are required. With your current psa and fpsa, I would suggest a bit more monitoring before risking a biopsy. What are 'PHI' and '4K'?

Posts.Title: What to ask at time of biopsy results?

Posts.Content: Ronald007, That wait time, whether the cancer is aggressive or not is totally unacceptable. 1-3 weeks would have been marginal. Do you have any other options besides your local prostate cancer center? Are you even being monitored for progression? Perhaps your doctor could put you on Lupron to slow or stop the growth while you wait. I don't know if that would improve your outcome or not but it might be worth looking into. Best of luck! --- Dave

Posts.Content: Nrhk2, I'm so sorry to hear of this. Your father is no longer suffering. As Rob said, you have no reason for guilt. You did everything you believed was right at the time. You are not expected to be God. I'm sure your dad relished the quality time he had with you in his final months. I wish I had been able to give my own parents the comfort and support that you have shown. Do not hold yourself to blame and remember him for who he was...your father. --- Dave

Posts.Title: One year after RP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster22 I stumbled upon this website by accident. I had never heard of this product before. It is really designed to replace condoms, but maybe has some value for guys with minimal incontinence like me. I slightly squirt, or loose a few drops of urine upon sneezing or coughing, especially when I am tired. I sent an email to jiftip, and they said it would work for minor incontinence like mine. I agree, it probably would work, but guys pee far more then have orgasms, so maybe not so practical. Still, it may have some practical incontinence use. Regardless, it is a novel approach for birth control, and std control. Who would ever have thought of creating a product like this?? http://www.jiftip.com/ http://www.jiftip.com/blog/the-promise Probably someone with a duct tape fetish.

Posts.Title: jiftip for minor incontinence??

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ErnestTBass I've read enough to say there seems to be a majority that agrees moderate exercise slightly increase testosterone levels particularly in those who have not been on an exercise plan . There also seems to be an overwhelming majority that agrees exercise should be an integral part of everyone's regiment to fight our common enemy PC. We all know testosterone feeds PC. To my question....can starting a moderate exercise program induce enough additional testosterone production to effect any residual cancer after treatment to the point it would cause a PSA "bounce" ? I think that's a great question...for your medical team.

Posts.Title: Goofy question of the day...

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm winging it a bit here and others with more experience may disagree but with a 5+4 and a PSA of 27, I would seriously consider brachy (seeds) with full pelvic radiation regardless of the scan results. Go for the cure, not the sex life. G9 is a BAD cancer. No HDT at this point as it will mask the results of the radiation. This should be discussed with your surgeon. Best of luck in whatever you decide. --- Dave

Posts.Title: Lupron Shots, side effects and cost

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by carolmullaley My husband was diagnosed in September 2015. Surgery was not an option. He had radiation and casodex and has now been on Lupron shots every 4 months. Been doing really good until recently. Got a shot in May. His PSA and testosterone levels barely readable. But in the last couple of weeks he has become extremely tired and says he very achy. He is working but it is a desk job. He comes home and is falling asleep by 7:30ish. I am worried. Should he get his levels rechecked Hi Carol, So sorry that you guys need to be here but you came to the right place. Do you think you could provide as many of his stats as possible? The folks on the forum will be able to give much better insight with them. More kind folks will be chiming in shortly. Cheers!

Posts.Title: Husband Gleason 9 (5+4)

Posts.Content: Hi and welcome. Sorry to hear about your bad experience. Nowadays, whether the degree is an MD, (doctor of medicine) or a DO (doctor of osteopathy) is really not that important as long as they trained at a reputable school. The training of a DO is almost identical to an MD except that the DO usually involves additional training over and above the standard curriculum. What IS important is that, either way, the person you see is an experienced, board certified urologist/surgeon. They have the training in that field that others do not. That's all they do. Hope that helps! PS: For what it's worth, my own PCP for many years now is a DO.

Posts.Title: Penile Injections

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Derkie54 Lancepease - Yes I am from the UK Anyone who has been through this. Is the radiation treatment normally successful and if it does not eliminate all of the PC is it just a case of doing it again ? Hi Derkie, I have just finished 35 IMRT treatments for positive margins. According to my RO, success is usually 60%-75%. If it fails to eradicate the tumor it cannot be done again in the same area. My concern in your case is the concurrent HT. According to my RO, if you do hormones along with radiotherapy, you will never know for sure that the radiation is working because the HT will very likely lower your PSA dramatically, effectively masking the effects of the radiation. Remember, radiation can potentially cure. HT cannot. I have no idea if that is generally the case or not but I think it's well worth asking your medical team about before you begin HT! Good luck! --- Dave

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JD1969 I took .15 my first time and had a RAGING boner for 3 hours. Trust me, on paper it seems like it would be fun, but after about 30 minutes it just becomes a pain. It really is not that bad. Here is a link to my first time with Bimix http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...ect-funny-long) "Raging Boner" What a great name for an indian warrior!
